_metadata.title: QIF Brain-BCI Unified Atlas
_metadata.description: Comprehensive machine-readable atlas unifying brain regions (38 structures across QIF 7-1-3 hourglass), BCI hardware (24 devices), device-region mappings, neural latency metrics, and physics constraints. Designed for dynamic visualization rendering and API consumption.
_metadata.primary_neuroanatomical_source: Kandel ER, et al. Principles of Neural Science. 6th ed. McGraw Hill, 2021
notes: Latency values are fastest documented response times from primary literature. Citations included per value.
Confidence levels: HIGH = primary literature with DOI; MEDIUM = review paper or textbook; LOW = inferred or estimated.
BCI device specs sourced from FDA filings, manufacturer datasheets, and peer-reviewed papers.
null values indicate data not publicly available.
Brain region IDs use snake_case. Device IDs use kebab-case.

qif_bands.name: Neocortex
qif_bands.description: Highest cortical processing — executive function, motor planning, sensory integration, language. Most complex and indeterminate neural band.

qif_bands.name: Limbic System
qif_bands.description: Emotion regulation, memory formation, interoception. Bridges cognitive and autonomic processing.

qif_bands.name: Basal Ganglia
qif_bands.description: Motor selection, habit formation, reward processing. Primary target of DBS for Parkinson's.

qif_bands.name: Diencephalon
qif_bands.description: Thalamic relay and gating of all ascending sensory traffic. Hypothalamic homeostasis. The brain's firewall layer.

qif_bands.name: Cerebellum
qif_bands.description: Motor coordination, timing, error correction, procedural learning. Contains >50% of the brain's neurons.

qif_bands.name: Brainstem
qif_bands.description: Vital functions — respiration, heart rate, blood pressure, arousal. Compromise is life-threatening.

qif_bands.name: Spinal Cord
qif_bands.description: Motor output and sensory input pathway. Local reflex arcs. Lowest neural band in the hourglass.

qif_bands.name: Neural Interface
qif_bands.description: Electrode-tissue boundary where biological signals become electronic. The bottleneck of the hourglass. Measurement collapses neural state space.

qif_bands.name: Analog Front-End
qif_bands.description: Amplification, filtering, ADC/DAC conversion. Analog noise introduces residual stochasticity.

qif_bands.name: Digital Processing
qif_bands.description: Decoding algorithms, classification, digital signal processing. Fully deterministic.

qif_bands.name: Application
qif_bands.description: Clinical software, user interface, data storage, network. Classical IT security domain.

brain_regions.name: Prefrontal Cortex
brain_regions.function: Executive function, decision-making, working memory, personality, social behavior, planning

response_latency_ms.measure: Visual stimulus to PFC neuronal onset
response_latency_ms.notes: Highly variable by task and stimulus type. Visual motion onset 40-60ms in frontal eye fields; decision-related activity 150-300ms.
citations: Sugase-Miyamoto et al. 2008 (PNAS): PFC population activity 100-200ms
Romanski & Hwang 2012 (PMC3618972): VLPFC vocalization response shortest latency

brain_regions.name: Primary Motor Cortex
brain_regions.function: Voluntary motor execution, somatotopic motor map (homunculus)

response_latency_ms.measure: Corticospinal conduction time to hand muscles
response_latency_ms.notes: Central motor conduction time (CMCT) measured via TMS: ~20ms to hand. Cortical motor neurons activate ~100-150ms before movement onset.
citations: Rossini et al. 2015: TMS guidelines, CMCT norms
Hallett 2007 (Neurology): TMS clinical neurophysiology

brain_regions.name: Primary Visual Cortex
brain_regions.function: Primary visual processing — edge detection, orientation, spatial frequency, color

response_latency_ms.measure: Visual stimulus to V1 ERP onset (C1 component)
response_latency_ms.notes: C1 component (N75): 56-100ms post-stimulus. Mean onset ~56ms (earliest reported). Intracranial: category decoding by 100ms.
citations: Clark et al. 1994 (Electroencephalogr Clin Neurophysiol): C1 mean onset 56ms
Di Russo et al. 2002 (PubMed 11797091): V1 source of C1 60-100ms
Liu et al. 2009 (J Neurosci): Object decoding from intracranial EEG at 100ms

brain_regions.name: Primary Auditory Cortex
brain_regions.function: Primary auditory processing — tonotopic frequency mapping, sound onset detection

response_latency_ms.measure: Auditory stimulus to cortical onset (Pa/high-gamma)
response_latency_ms.notes: Middle-latency response Pa: 25-40ms. High-gamma (70-150 Hz) cortical response ~40ms. Full cortical processing: Na 12-27ms, Pa 25-40ms.
citations: Liégeois-Chauvel et al. 1994 (J Neurosci): First-spike timing in auditory cortex
Nourski et al. 2022 (PMC9773383): Time-locked high-gamma responses at ~40ms
Picton et al. 2010 (PMC9443762): Middle-latency auditory response norms

brain_regions.name: Broca's Area
brain_regions.function: Speech production, syntactic processing, language planning

response_latency_ms.measure: Three sequential processing waves during linguistic tasks (human intracranial)
response_latency_ms.notes: Unique three-wave pattern: ~200ms (lexical), ~320ms (grammatical), ~450ms (phonological) — Flinker et al. 2015, intracranial EEG. High-gamma (70-150 Hz) during speech production and perception.
citations: Flinker et al. 2015 (PNAS): Three-wave pattern ~200/320/450ms in Broca's area
Sahin et al. 2009 (Science): Intracranial recordings lexical ~200ms, grammatical ~320ms, phonological ~450ms

brain_regions.name: Wernicke's Area
brain_regions.function: Language comprehension, semantic processing, speech reception

response_latency_ms.measure: Auditory speech to posterior STG high-gamma onset (human intracranial)
response_latency_ms.notes: High-gamma onset in posterior STG: ~50-100ms (intracranial, Mesgarani & Chang 2012). N400 semantic component peaks ~400ms. MMN at ~100-200ms for deviant phonemes.
citations: Mesgarani & Chang 2012 (Nature 485:233-236): STG speech response onset ~50ms
Kutas & Federmeier 2011 (Annu Rev Psychol): N400 review

brain_regions.name: Premotor Cortex
brain_regions.function: Motor planning, movement preparation, sensorimotor integration

response_latency_ms.measure: Visual cue to premotor neuron firing onset
response_latency_ms.notes: Premotor neurons fire 80-200ms before movement onset. Visually guided reach: ~120ms.
citations: Churchland et al. 2010 (Neuron): Preparatory activity in premotor cortex

brain_regions.name: Supplementary Motor Area
brain_regions.function: Motor sequence planning, bimanual coordination, internally generated movements

response_latency_ms.measure: Bereitschaftspotential (readiness potential) before movement
response_latency_ms.notes: Readiness potential begins ~1500ms before voluntary movement onset. SMA proper activates ~500ms before movement.
citations: Shibasaki & Hallett 2006 (Clin Neurophysiol): Bereitschaftspotential review

brain_regions.name: Posterior Parietal Cortex
brain_regions.function: Spatial awareness, sensorimotor integration, attention, reach planning

response_latency_ms.measure: Visual stimulus to LIP neuron onset (macaque single-unit); human intracranial ~60ms
response_latency_ms.notes: Mean latency 45.2ms in macaque area LIP (Bisley et al. 2004). Human posterior IPS: ~60ms (Hertz et al. 2018, intracranial). P1 ERP component over parietal cortex: ~100ms.
citations: Bisley et al. 2004 (J Neurosci 24(8):1833, DOI: 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5007-03.2004): Mean latency 45.2ms
Hertz et al. 2018 (DOI: 10.1101/377887): Human intracranial ~60ms

brain_regions.name: Primary Somatosensory Cortex
brain_regions.function: Tactile sensation, proprioception, somatotopic sensory map (homunculus)

response_latency_ms.measure: Somatosensory evoked potential (SEP) N20 component
response_latency_ms.notes: N20 component at ~20ms post-median nerve stimulus. Earliest cortical SEP. P14 (subcortical) at ~14ms.
citations: Allison et al. 1991 (Cereb Cortex): Human cortical somatosensory evoked potentials
Cruccu et al. 2008 (Clin Neurophysiol): SEP guidelines

brain_regions.name: Hippocampus
brain_regions.function: Episodic memory formation, spatial navigation, memory consolidation

response_latency_ms.measure: Visual stimulus to hippocampal single-neuron response (human intracranial)
response_latency_ms.notes: Median onset 204ms for visually responsive neurons (Mormann et al. 2008, human intracranial). Hierarchical: parahippocampal cortex ~101ms, entorhinal cortex ~206ms, hippocampus ~204ms. Sharp-wave ripples (SWR): 80-200 Hz, ~50-100ms duration.
citations: Mormann, Kornblith, Quiroga et al. 2008 (J Neurosci 28(36):8865-8872, DOI: 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.1640-08.2008): Median onset 204ms
Buzsaki 2015 (Neuron): Sharp-wave ripples review

brain_regions.name: Basolateral Amygdala
brain_regions.function: Fear conditioning, emotional valence assignment, associative learning. Cortical-like architecture.

response_latency_ms.measure: Visual threat stimulus to amygdala response (intracranial EEG)
response_latency_ms.notes: Fastest documented: ~74ms via intracranial EEG (Mendez-Bertolo et al. 2016). NOT 12ms — no source exists for sub-20ms amygdala response. The 'fast path' bypasses thalamic gating but still requires ~74ms.
citations: Mendez-Bertolo et al. 2016 (Nature Neuroscience): Amygdala response to fear at 74ms via intracranial EEG

brain_regions.name: Insular Cortex
brain_regions.function: Interoception, pain processing, emotional awareness, taste, autonomic regulation

response_latency_ms.measure: Auditory stimulus to insular HFA onset (human intracranial EEG)
response_latency_ms.notes: Intracranial EEG: 200-350ms for auditory stimuli. Visual P300-like component in anterior insula: 250-338ms. Substantially slower than primary sensory cortices, consistent with higher-order integrative role.
citations: Demarchi et al. 2019 (PMID: 31629197): Auditory deviance response in insula
Ibos et al. 2019 (DOI: 10.1007/s00429-019-01892-y): Visual oddball insular response

brain_regions.name: Anterior Cingulate Cortex
brain_regions.function: Conflict monitoring, error detection, pain processing, motivation, autonomic regulation

response_latency_ms.measure: ERN (Error-Related Negativity) onset
response_latency_ms.notes: Error-related negativity (ERN) peaks ~80-150ms post-error. Conflict monitoring (N2): ~200-350ms. Pain processing: ~150-250ms.
citations: Gehring et al. 2012 (Oxford Handbook): ERN and ACC

brain_regions.name: Cingulate Gyrus (Posterior)
brain_regions.function: Default mode network hub, self-referential processing, memory retrieval, spatial orientation

response_latency_ms.measure: Task-related deactivation/activation
response_latency_ms.notes: Part of default mode network. Deactivation during task onset: ~200-300ms. Memory-related activation: variable.
citations: Raichle 2015 (Neuron): Default mode network review

brain_regions.name: Striatum (Caudate + Putamen)
brain_regions.function: Motor selection, habit learning, reward prediction, action initiation

response_latency_ms.measure: Reward-related or movement-related striatal firing
response_latency_ms.notes: Reward prediction error: ~100ms post-outcome. Movement-related: ~60-200ms before movement in putamen. Caudate: 100-300ms for cognitive tasks.
citations: Schultz 2006 (Annu Rev Psychol): Reward signals in basal ganglia

brain_regions.name: Globus Pallidus Internus
brain_regions.function: Primary output nucleus of basal ganglia (inhibitory). Major DBS target for dystonia.

response_latency_ms.measure: Striatal input to GPi output latency
response_latency_ms.notes: Direct pathway: striatum → GPi ~10-15ms. GPi tonic firing rate: 60-80 Hz. Pause latency during movement: ~15ms.
citations: Kita & Kita 2011 (J Neurosci): Basal ganglia circuit timing

brain_regions.name: Globus Pallidus Externus
brain_regions.function: Indirect pathway relay, tonic inhibition of STN, basal ganglia modulation

response_latency_ms.measure: Striatal input to GPe relay
response_latency_ms.notes: Similar timing to GPi. Tonic firing rate: 50-70 Hz. Indirect pathway involves additional STN relay.
citations: Kita & Kita 2011 (J Neurosci): Basal ganglia circuit timing

brain_regions.name: Subthalamic Nucleus
brain_regions.function: Hyperdirect pathway hub, motor urgency signal, stop-signal processing. Primary DBS target for Parkinson's.

response_latency_ms.measure: Cortical stimulation to STN response (antidromic/orthodromic)
response_latency_ms.notes: Short-latency (antidromic via hyperdirect pathway): 5-10ms. Medium-latency (antidromic cortical): 2-15ms. Long-latency (orthodromic polysynaptic): 20-70ms. Beta oscillations (15-30 Hz) pathological in PD.
citations: Nambu et al. 2002 (J Neurophysiol): Hyperdirect pathway timing
Miocinovic et al. 2018 (JAMA Neurol): STN DBS mechanisms
Walker et al. 2012 (PMC2852267): Short-latency visual input to STN via superior colliculus

brain_regions.name: Substantia Nigra
brain_regions.function: Dopamine production (SNc, pars compacta) and basal ganglia output (SNr, pars reticulata). Degeneration causes Parkinson's.

response_latency_ms.measure: Dopamine burst latency to unexpected reward
response_latency_ms.notes: SNc dopamine neurons: burst response to unexpected reward ~10-20ms. SNr inhibitory output timing similar to GPi.
citations: Schultz 1998 (J Neurophysiol): Dopamine neuron temporal dynamics

brain_regions.name: Thalamus
brain_regions.function: Central relay station for all sensory modalities (except olfaction). Gating via reticular thalamic nucleus (TRN) implements default-deny on ascending traffic.

response_latency_ms.measure: LGN relay latency (retina → LGN → V1)
response_latency_ms.notes: LGN visual relay: ~4.2ms (retinogeniculate delay). VPL somatosensory relay: ~14ms (median nerve). MGN auditory relay: ~6-8ms. TRN gating adds ~2-5ms.
citations: Sherman & Guillery 2006 (Exploring the Thalamus and Its Role in Cortical Function): Thalamic relay timing
Briggs & Usrey 2011 (Neuron): LGN response properties

brain_regions.name: Hypothalamus
brain_regions.function: Homeostatic regulation — temperature, hunger, thirst, circadian rhythm, hormone release, autonomic output

response_latency_ms.measure: Lateral hypothalamus evoked potential to sciatic nerve stimulation (cat)
response_latency_ms.notes: Lateral hypothalamus: ~7ms (cat, evoked potential). Acoustic/somatosensory: <15-20ms across mammals. Homeostatic outputs operate on seconds-to-hours timescale. CAUTION: 7ms value from animal data — human intracranial data extremely limited.
citations: Yamamoto et al. 2020 (Physiol Behav, DOI: 10.1016/j.physbeh.2020.113100): Fast sensory responses in lateral hypothalamus review

brain_regions.name: Ventral Intermediate Nucleus (Thalamus)
brain_regions.function: Cerebellar relay to motor cortex. Primary DBS target for essential tremor.

response_latency_ms.measure: Cerebellothalamic conduction time
response_latency_ms.notes: Dentate nucleus to VIM: ~5-8ms. VIM to motor cortex: ~3-5ms. Total cerebellar loop: ~20-40ms.
citations: Middleton & Strick 2000 (Brain Res Rev): Basal ganglia and cerebellar loops

brain_regions.name: Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus
brain_regions.function: Limbic relay, memory circuits (Papez circuit). DBS target for drug-resistant epilepsy.

response_latency_ms.measure: Hippocampal input relay time
response_latency_ms.notes: Mammillothalamic tract conduction to ANT: ~5-10ms. ANT to cingulate cortex: ~5-10ms.
citations: Fisher et al. 2010 (Epilepsia): SANTE trial, ANT DBS for epilepsy

brain_regions.name: Cerebellar Cortex
brain_regions.function: Motor coordination, error correction, timing, procedural learning. Purkinje cells are the sole output.

response_latency_ms.measure: Mossy fiber input to Purkinje cell response
response_latency_ms.notes: Climbing fiber input: ~10ms. Mossy fiber → granule cell → parallel fiber → Purkinje cell: ~15-25ms. Complex spike latency: ~10ms from IO input. Purkinje cells fire at 30-100 Hz tonic.
citations: Heck et al. 2013 (PubMed 23970855): Purkinje cell rebound timing
Johansson et al. 2014 (PNAS): Memory trace timing in Purkinje cells

brain_regions.name: Deep Cerebellar Nuclei
brain_regions.function: Cerebellar output nuclei (dentate, interposed, fastigial). Relay to thalamus and brainstem.

response_latency_ms.measure: Purkinje cell inhibition to nuclear rebound firing
response_latency_ms.notes: Rebound firing after Purkinje cell pause: ~15ms. Dentate nucleus to thalamus: ~5-8ms.
citations: Heck et al. 2013 (PubMed 23970855): Rebound activity in cerebellar nuclei

brain_regions.name: Cerebellar Vermis
brain_regions.function: Axial motor control, balance, gait, vestibular integration, emotional regulation

response_latency_ms.measure: Vestibular input to vermis response
response_latency_ms.notes: Vestibulocerebellar projections: ~10-20ms. Vermis involved in both motor and emotional processing (Schmahmann dysmetria of thought).
citations: Schmahmann 2019 (Cerebellum): Cerebellar cognitive affective syndrome

brain_regions.name: Medulla Oblongata
brain_regions.function: Vital autonomic centers — respiratory rhythm, cardiac center, blood pressure (vasomotor), vomiting reflex

response_latency_ms.measure: BAEP Wave II (cochlear nuclei in rostral medulla)
response_latency_ms.notes: Brainstem auditory evoked potential Wave II: 2-4ms post-stimulus. Cochlear nuclei generate Wave II. Medullary autonomic reflexes: 5-20ms.
citations: NCBI Bookshelf NBK597358: Brainstem auditory evoked response norms
Hall 2007 (New Handbook of Auditory Evoked Responses): BAEP wave generators

brain_regions.name: Pons
brain_regions.function: Relay between cortex and cerebellum, REM sleep regulation, auditory relay (superior olivary complex)

response_latency_ms.measure: BAEP Wave III (superior olivary complex in caudal pons)
response_latency_ms.notes: BAEP Wave III: 3-5ms. Superior olivary complex generates Wave III. Pontine nuclei relay cortical signals to cerebellum.
citations: NCBI Bookshelf NBK597358: BAEP wave generators
Wikipedia: Brainstem auditory evoked potential

brain_regions.name: Midbrain (Mesencephalon)
brain_regions.function: Visual/auditory reflexes (superior/inferior colliculi), dopaminergic pathways (VTA, SNc), pain modulation (PAG)

response_latency_ms.measure: BAEP Wave V (inferior colliculus vicinity)
response_latency_ms.notes: BAEP Wave V: 7-9ms. Inferior colliculus response. Superior colliculus visual saccade response: ~40-70ms.
citations: NCBI Bookshelf NBK597358: BAEP Wave V generator
Walker et al. 2012 (PMC2852267): Superior colliculus to STN short-latency visual input

brain_regions.name: Reticular Formation
brain_regions.function: Arousal, consciousness, sleep-wake transitions, pain modulation, postural tone

response_latency_ms.measure: Stimulus to arousal response
response_latency_ms.notes: Reticular activating system (RAS) response to salient stimuli: ~10-50ms. Startle reflex (reticulospinal): ~14ms. Muscle tone modulation: 10-20ms.
citations: Moruzzi & Magoun 1949 (EEG Clin Neurophysiol): Reticular activating system (classic)
Brown et al. 1991 (Exp Brain Res): Reticulospinal reflex latency

brain_regions.name: Cervical Spinal Cord
brain_regions.function: Upper limb motor innervation, diaphragm (C3-C5), neck muscles, upper limb sensation

response_latency_ms.measure: Corticospinal tract to cervical motor neuron
response_latency_ms.notes: Central motor conduction time to upper limbs: ~6-8ms (TMS). Peripheral conduction adds ~10-15ms.
citations: Rossini et al. 2015: TMS guidelines

brain_regions.name: Thoracic Spinal Cord
brain_regions.function: Trunk muscles, sympathetic outflow, intercostal muscles for respiration

response_latency_ms.measure: Corticospinal conduction to thoracic segments
response_latency_ms.notes: Longer conduction distance than cervical. Sympathetic preganglionic neurons here.

brain_regions.name: Lumbar Spinal Cord
brain_regions.function: Lower limb motor innervation, patellar reflex, lower limb sensation

response_latency_ms.measure: Corticospinal conduction to lumbar motor neurons
response_latency_ms.notes: Central motor conduction time to lower limbs: ~14-16ms (TMS). Patellar reflex arc: ~15-30ms total.
citations: Rossini et al. 2015: TMS guidelines

brain_regions.name: Sacral Spinal Cord
brain_regions.function: Bladder, bowel, sexual function, perineal sensation, parasympathetic outflow

response_latency_ms.measure: Corticospinal conduction to sacral segments
response_latency_ms.notes: Longest corticospinal conduction. Pudendal nerve latency: ~35-40ms total (central + peripheral).

brain_regions.name: Cauda Equina
brain_regions.function: Bundle of spinal nerve roots below L1-L2. Lower limb motor/sensory, bladder, bowel.

response_latency_ms.notes: Peripheral nerve bundle, not a CNS structure. Conduction velocity depends on individual nerve roots (~50-60 m/s).

brain_regions.name: Central Amygdala
brain_regions.function: Autonomic fear output, conditioned fear responses, pain modulation. Subcortical architecture (unlike BLA).

response_latency_ms.measure: BLA input to CeA autonomic output
response_latency_ms.notes: CeA receives processed input from BLA. Output drives autonomic responses (heart rate, freezing) with ~100-200ms latency from stimulus.
citations: LeDoux 2000 (Annu Rev Neurosci): Emotion circuits

bci_devices: SEE docs/bci-hardware-inventory.json — 24 devices with full hardware specs. This field cross-references device IDs for the mapping table below.

device_region_mappings.notes: 1024-channel cortical implant in motor cortex. Read-only (recording spikes + LFP).
Next-gen: motor + visual cortex targets. Stimulation planned for vision restoration.
96-128 channels, penetrating electrodes. SIROF variant enables stimulation. Gold standard for cortical recording.
Uses Utah Arrays. Wireless variant: 48 Mbps, >36h battery. First home-use wireless intracortical BCI.
Responsive neurostimulation at seizure foci. Depth electrodes reach hippocampus, amygdala. Surface strips for cortical foci.
DBS + BrainSense LFP recording. Primary targets: STN (PD), GPi (dystonia), VIM (tremor).
Rechargeable variant. Same brain targets as Percept PC. >15 year service life.
Endovascular (superior sagittal sinus). Adjacent to motor cortex but inside blood vessel. No direct tissue contact.
Cochlear implant stimulates auditory nerve (CN VIII). Signal reaches A1 via brainstem auditory pathway. 22 electrodes.
Cochlear implant. 12 channels, longest electrode arrays (up to 34mm) for complete cochlear coverage.
DBS stimulation only (no sensing). 16-contact directional leads (Cartesia). 25-year rechargeable battery.
DBS with directional stimulation. Smallest non-rechargeable DBS device at launch. 8-contact segmented leads.
14-channel consumer EEG. Scalp recording. Volume conduction limits spatial resolution to ~cm scale. Saline felt sensors.
5-channel consumer EEG. Minimal coverage: frontal + temporal + parietal.
8-channel (expandable to 16) open-source EEG. ADS1299 24-bit ADC. Research-grade for non-invasive BCI.
4-channel entry-level open-source EEG. BLE. 18-bit effective resolution.
4-channel consumer EEG headband. Frontal + temporal positions. Dry electrodes. Primary use: meditation.
4 EEG + 2 auxiliary channels. Sleep tracking focus. Same electrode positions as Muse 2.
128-channel ECoG (subdural). Speech + hand motor areas. Temporary (6-month) implantation. Hopkins consortium.
421-1681 channels. Intracortical microwires (1.5mm depth). Near-infrared optical data link (not RF).
1024-channel thin-film cortical array (5um thick). Minimally invasive: inserted through <1mm slit. 510(k) cleared for intraoperative use.
8-channel research EEG. Hybrid dry/gel electrodes. 24-bit ADC. Bluetooth.
2000+ optical channels (TD-fNIRS). Hemodynamic imaging (not electrical). 52 modules. Whole-head coverage.
Research program (5 teams). Target: 16 channels in 16mm3 within 50ms. Approaches: acousto-optical, magnetoelectric nanotransducers, OPMs.

ihtt_ms.notes: Visual IHTT via splenium of corpus callosum. Measured by P100 ERP laterality or CUD in reaction time. Correlates with myelination integrity.
citations: Schulte et al. 2006 (PubMed 17034948): IHTT and corpus callosum structural properties
Saron & Davidson 1989: CUD of 3-4ms in normal adults

thermal_limit.description: Maximum allowable tissue temperature rise at electrode-tissue interface

sar_limit.description: Specific absorption rate limit (10g averaged, 6 min)

shannon_safety_limit.description: Shannon's charge density / charge per phase limit for safe neural stimulation. k=1.75 is the conservative safety boundary.

boltzmann_thermal_noise.equation: V_noise = sqrt(4 * k_B * T * R * BW)
boltzmann_thermal_noise.description: Johnson-Nyquist thermal noise floor at electrode-tissue interface. Sets fundamental limit on signal detection.

stevensons_law.description: Simultaneously recorded neurons doubles every ~7.4 years. BCI 'Moore's Law'.

moores_law_realized.description: Real-world transistor density doubling: ~3 years (60-65% of theoretical 2-year). Consistent across Intel, Nvidia, Apple silicon.
moores_law_realized.source: QIF derivation (Entry 60, validated against Intel Pentium-to-Arrow Lake and Nvidia Tesla-to-Blackwell)

external_atlas_references.name: Allen Brain Atlas API
external_atlas_references.notes: Mouse brain ontology. Human brain atlas also available. Direct JSON download of structure hierarchy.

external_atlas_references.name: BrainGlobe AtlasAPI
external_atlas_references.notes: Python package wrapping multiple atlases in unified JSON format. pip install brainglobe-atlasapi.

external_atlas_references.name: BAMS (Brain Architecture Management System)
external_atlas_references.notes: 63K+ neuroanatomical reports. 10K+ nomenclature entries. Connectivity inference engine.

external_atlas_references.name: AAL Atlas (Automated Anatomical Labeling)
external_atlas_references.notes: Standard brain parcellation. Available via Python nilearn.datasets.fetch_atlas_aal.

source_bibliography.citation: Kandel ER, Koester JD, Mack SH, Siegelbaum SA. Principles of Neural Science. 6th ed. McGraw Hill; 2021.
source_bibliography.relevance: Primary source for QIF 7-band neuroanatomical hierarchy and 38 brain region assignments.

source_bibliography.citation: Mendez-Bertolo C, et al. A fast pathway for fear in human amygdala. Nat Neurosci. 2016;19(8):1041-1049.
source_bibliography.relevance: Verified amygdala response latency: ~74ms. Corrects fabricated 12ms claim.

source_bibliography.citation: Stevenson IH, Kording KP. How advances in neural recording affect data analysis. Nat Neurosci. 2011;14(2):139-142.
source_bibliography.relevance: Stevenson's Law: simultaneously recorded neurons doubles every ~7.4 years.

source_bibliography.citation: Shannon RV. A model of safe levels for electrical stimulation. IEEE Trans Biomed Eng. 1992;39(4):424-426.
source_bibliography.relevance: Shannon safety limit for neural stimulation charge density.

source_bibliography.citation: Sherman SM, Guillery RW. Exploring the Thalamus and Its Role in Cortical Function. 2nd ed. MIT Press; 2006.
source_bibliography.relevance: Thalamic relay timing and gating mechanisms.

source_bibliography.citation: Brainstem Auditory Evoked Response Test. StatPearls. NCBI Bookshelf NBK597358.
source_bibliography.relevance: BAEP wave generators and normal latency values for brainstem structures.
